tasks.title: Implement saved-searches create/delete/enable/disable (CLI + TUI)
tasks.description:
Opportunity type: feature gap / workflow coverage

Evidence:
- CLI saved searches are limited to list/info/run/edit (`crates/cli/src/commands/saved_searches.rs`), with explicit non-goal of scheduling. There is no create/delete or enable/disable command surface.
- TUI Saved Searches screen supports run/edit/export, but not create/delete or enable/disable (keybindings in README).
- The client already has `create_saved_search`, `delete_saved_search`, and `update_saved_search(..., disabled)` (`crates/client/src/client/search.rs`).

Why it matters:
- Saves time by enabling full lifecycle management from the terminal: create -> iterate -> disable/enable -> delete.
- Reduces reliance on Splunk Web for routine knowledge-object management.

Proposed approach:
- Minimal slice:
  - CLI: add `splunk-cli saved-searches create <NAME> --search <SPL>` and `delete <NAME> [--force]`, plus `enable/disable <NAME>` wrappers.
  - TUI: add `n` (new), `d` (delete with confirmation), and `t` (toggle disabled) on Saved Searches screen using the existing popup/action patterns.
- Expansion: add namespace flags (`--app`, `--owner`) if supported by endpoints; add schedule editing as a later phase.

Risks and mitigations:
- Risk: destructive operations. Mitigation: confirmations + `--force` in CLI, confirm modal in TUI, and clear error messaging.

Acceptance criteria:
- CLI help updated with examples; error messages match repo conventions.
- Hermetic tests cover arg parsing and non-network failure modes; ignored live tests cover success paths.
- TUI keybindings docs are regenerated and reflect new actions.
- `make test` passes.

Priority rationale:
- High: closes a real end-to-end workflow gap using existing client capabilities.
evidence: crates/cli/src/commands/saved_searches.rs defines only List/Info/Run/Edit subcommands (no Create/Delete/Enable/Disable)
crates/client/src/client/search.rs exposes create_saved_search(), delete_saved_search(), and update_saved_search(disabled)
README.md keybindings for Saved Searches show run/edit/export but no create/delete
plan: Extend `SavedSearchesCommand` to include create/delete/enable/disable with safe confirmation semantics.
Add corresponding client calls in CLI command handlers, reusing existing `SplunkClient` methods.
Add TUI actions + popups for create/delete/toggle-disabled on Saved Searches screen.
Add hermetic tests for CLI parsing and TUI state transitions; add `#[ignore]` live tests for server-backed behavior.
Regenerate keybinding docs (`make generate`) and verify docs drift check passes.
Verify by running `make test` and confirming `make ci` remains green.

tasks.title: Add lookup download/upload/delete (client + CLI + TUI)
tasks.description:
Opportunity type: feature gap / integration

Evidence:
- The client lookup module only lists lookup tables and explicitly does not handle upload/download (`crates/client/src/client/lookups.rs`).
- CLI and TUI expose lookup listing but not content management (docs show `splunk-cli lookups` list; TUI Lookups screen focuses on list/export).

Why it matters:
- Lookup tables are a core Splunk workflow for enrichment. Without download/upload/delete, users must leave the terminal for everyday maintenance.

Proposed approach:
- Minimal slice:
  - Client: add endpoints for downloading a lookup file (CSV) and uploading/replacing a lookup file, plus deleting a lookup.
  - CLI: add `lookups download/upload/delete` subcommands with safe defaults and `--force` for delete.
  - TUI: add at least download (export) and delete, with a preview modal as a follow-up.
- Expansion: namespace support (`app`, `owner`) and KV store lookup workflows.

Risks and mitigations:
- Risk: endpoint shape differences across Splunk versions. Mitigation: implement with explicit integration tests under `#[ignore]` and robust error reporting; document supported versions (v9+).

Acceptance criteria:
- New client methods with unit tests for request building/parsing where possible; live tests validate end-to-end.
- CLI help includes examples for download/upload and piping-friendly output.
- TUI keybindings updated + docs regenerated.
- `make test` passes.

Priority rationale:
- High: enables a common Splunk admin workflow end-to-end from the terminal.
evidence: crates/client/src/client/lookups.rs states it does NOT handle lookup file content upload/download
docs/usage.md documents `splunk-cli lookups` listing and output formats but not download/upload/delete workflows
README.md keybindings include Lookups screen with refresh/export/copy but no view/download/upload/delete actions
plan: Confirm the Splunk REST endpoints for lookup file download/upload/delete (document links in docs as needed).
Implement client endpoints and models, keeping public API minimal (`pub(crate)` where possible).
Add CLI subcommands for download/upload/delete with safe confirmations.
Add TUI actions for at least download/export and delete (confirmation modal).

tasks.title: Centralize SPLUNK_CONFIG_PATH/SPLUNK_PROFILE handling in splunk_config
tasks.description:
Opportunity type: modernization / reliability

Evidence:
- The docs claim `SPLUNK_CONFIG_PATH` and `SPLUNK_PROFILE` work for both CLI and TUI (`docs/usage.md`).
- CLI and TUI implement these env vars manually (e.g., TUI checks `env_var_or_none("SPLUNK_CONFIG_PATH")` in `crates/tui/src/main.rs`).
- The config env loader applies many env vars but does not apply `SPLUNK_CONFIG_PATH` or `SPLUNK_PROFILE` (`crates/config/src/loader/env.rs`).

Why it matters:
- Duplicated precedence logic tends to drift and causes hard-to-debug inconsistencies across UI surfaces.

Proposed approach:
- Add first-class support in `ConfigLoader` for config-path + profile env vars (with empty/whitespace filtering), matching the documented precedence rules.
- Update CLI/TUI to delegate to `splunk_config` for env resolution, leaving only CLI-arg override logic at the app edge.

Risks and mitigations:
- Risk: subtle precedence changes. Mitigation: codify precedence in tests and update docs alongside code.

Acceptance criteria:
- New unit tests in `crates/config` covering env parsing and precedence (blank env var values ignored).
- CLI/TUI code removes duplicated env-var logic and continues to behave as documented.
- `make test` passes.

Priority rationale:
- Medium: reduces future bugs and keeps CLI/TUI consistent.
evidence: docs/usage.md:84-96 documents SPLUNK_CONFIG_PATH and SPLUNK_PROFILE
crates/config/src/loader/env.rs applies SPLUNK_BASE_URL, SPLUNK_USERNAME, etc, but not SPLUNK_CONFIG_PATH/SPLUNK_PROFILE
crates/tui/src/main.rs:165-170 manually reads SPLUNK_CONFIG_PATH env var
plan: Add env parsing for `SPLUNK_CONFIG_PATH` and `SPLUNK_PROFILE` inside `splunk_config::ConfigLoader` (or a shared helper).
Update CLI and TUI startup to rely on the centralized loader behavior.
Add config crate tests proving precedence + blank-value behavior matches docs.
Update docs to reflect the single source of truth.
Verify by running `make test` and confirming config loader tests pass.

tasks.title: Fix config precedence docs + add Quick Verify onboarding
tasks.description:
Opportunity type: UX improvement (docs)

Evidence:
- README lists precedence as CLI args -> env vars -> profile -> defaults, but `docs/usage.md` states `.env` is loaded first before CLI parsing, and documents a different loading order that includes `.env`.
- README onboarding lacks a single quick verification command; the user guide contains troubleshooting, but new users reading only README don't get a fast sanity check.

Why it matters:
- Misunderstood precedence leads to misconfiguration and wasted debugging time.
- A quick "first successful call" reduces setup friction and improves adoption.

Proposed approach:
- Unify precedence wording across `README.md`, `docs/usage.md`, and `docs/user-guide.md` by explicitly separating:
  - dotenv load timing (before clap parsing)
  - override precedence (CLI flags override env/profile/defaults)
- Add a "Quick Verify" section in `README.md` (recommended: `splunk-cli health` and expected output patterns), plus a pointer to `splunk-cli doctor` once implemented.

Risks and mitigations:
- Risk: docs drift again. Mitigation: keep generated keybindings isolated and add a docs-lint note for precedence sections.

Acceptance criteria:
- Updated docs show a single, consistent precedence order and explicitly mention `.env` load behavior.
- README includes at least one fast verification flow and a troubleshooting link.
- `make lint-docs` passes.

Priority rationale:
- Medium: reduces onboarding friction and support load.
evidence: README.md:131-137 documents precedence without mentioning `.env` layer
docs/usage.md:68-78 documents loading order starting with `.env` before CLI parsing
README.md lacks a single 'run X and expect Y' verification step
plan: Update README/docs to converge on a single configuration precedence explanation (include `.env` load timing and override semantics).
Add a Quick Verify section to README using existing CLI commands (health/search/indexes) with expected outcomes.
Run `make lint-docs` to ensure generated sections remain consistent.
Verify by running `make lint-docs` and confirming no docs drift is reported.

tasks.title: Make TUI 'r' key a true refresh (not pagination)
tasks.description:
Opportunity type: UX improvement

Evidence:
- Several TUI keybindings label `r` as "Refresh ..." but bind to `LoadMore*` actions, which is pagination rather than refresh.

Why it matters:
- Users expect refresh to reload current data from the beginning. Pagination on `r` makes the UI feel unpredictable and can hide failures (you think you refreshed; you actually appended).

Proposed approach:
- Minimal slice: redefine `r` to reset pagination state and trigger a load at `offset=0` (true refresh) on affected screens (Jobs, Indexes, Apps, Users, etc.).
- Add an explicit "Load more" key (e.g., `L`) for pagination to keep the capability discoverable.
- Regenerate keybinding docs to match behavior.

Risks and mitigations:
- Risk: users accustomed to current behavior. Mitigation: include release note in docs; add a toast the first time the new load-more key is used.

Acceptance criteria:
- Keybindings and help text match behavior; `r` reliably reloads from offset 0 and clears selection/pagination as specified.
- TUI tests cover pagination reset semantics.
- `make test` passes.

Priority rationale:
- Medium: removes a repeated UX papercut across many screens.
evidence: crates/tui/src/input/keymap/bindings/jobs.rs:25-35 describes 'Refresh jobs' but action is Action::LoadMoreJobs
crates/tui/src/input/keymap/bindings/screens/indexes.rs:22-33 describes 'Refresh indexes' but action is Action::LoadMoreIndexes
plan: Identify all screens where `r` is described as refresh but mapped to `LoadMore*`.
Introduce (or reuse) explicit refresh actions that load with offset=0 and reset pagination state.
Add a dedicated 'Load more' binding and update the keymap docs generator output.
Add TUI tests validating refresh resets pagination and load-more advances offset.
Verify by running `make generate` and `make test` and confirming docs + tests pass.

tasks.title: Make TUI footer/help hints mode- and override-aware
tasks.description:
Opportunity type: UX improvement / reliability

Evidence:
- The footer always prints "Tab:Next Screen | Shift+Tab:Previous Screen" (`crates/tui/src/app/render.rs`), but Search QueryFocused mode consumes `Tab` for focus toggling and explicitly bypasses global bindings (`crates/tui/src/app.rs`).
- Footer hints are cached from the default keybinding catalog and do not reflect user keybind overrides (`crates/tui/src/input/keymap/mod.rs` builds FOOTER_HINTS_CACHE from `keybindings()` without overlays).
- The footer hints cache relies on a manually maintained screen list (`all_screens()`), which can drift when new screens are added.

Why it matters:
- Incorrect hints teach the wrong mental model and slow users down. Overrides that don't show up in help make customization feel broken.
- Drift in screen lists causes missing hints and hard-to-spot UX regressions.

Proposed approach:
- Minimal slice:
  - Make footer navigation hints context-aware for Search (QueryFocused: show "Tab:Toggle Focus", keep screen navigation on `Shift+Tab` and/or `Ctrl+Tab`).
  - Build help/footer hints from an effective keymap (defaults + overrides) after overrides are initialized.
  - Add tests asserting `all_screens()` matches `CurrentScreen` variants and that Search footer hints differ by input mode.

Risks and mitigations:
- Risk: increased runtime work. Mitigation: keep caching, but regenerate cache after applying overrides (one-time).

Acceptance criteria:
- Help/footer hints match actual behavior for Search mode and overridden bindings.
- Regression tests prevent screen list drift.
- `make test` passes.

Priority rationale:
- Medium: improves ergonomics across every session and reduces confusion.
evidence: crates/tui/src/app/render.rs:695-712 hardcodes footer nav width for 'Tab:Next Screen' and renders it unconditionally
crates/tui/src/app.rs:453-461 skips global bindings for Tab/BackTab in Search QueryFocused mode
crates/tui/src/input/keymap/mod.rs:111-148 precomputes FOOTER_HINTS_CACHE from default keybindings and does not incorporate overrides
plan: Update footer rendering to select navigation hints based on current screen + input mode (Search QueryFocused vs ResultsFocused).
Introduce an 'effective keybindings' view that merges overrides into the help/footer catalog, and regenerate cache after overrides init.
Add tests for screen list drift and for override-aware hint rendering.
Verify by running `make test` and confirming snapshot/help tests still pass.

tasks.title: Ignore stale SPL validation results in TUI
tasks.description:
Opportunity type: reliability / UX improvement

Evidence:
- SPL validation is debounced, but validation requests are executed asynchronously and results do not carry the originating query or a request id (`Action::SplValidationResult` lacks any correlation field).
- Under latency, out-of-order responses can overwrite the UI state with errors/warnings for a previous query.

Why it matters:
- Users can see incorrect validation errors for text they've already edited away, undermining trust in the validator and increasing friction while typing.

Proposed approach:
- Minimal slice: add a monotonically-increasing `validation_request_id` (or hash of the query) to both the request action and the result action. Store the latest id in App state and ignore results that don't match the latest request.
- Optional: cancel in-flight validation tasks when a new validation is scheduled (abort join handle), to reduce server load.

Risks and mitigations:
- Risk: more state plumbing. Mitigation: keep the id small and local to the Search screen state; add focused tests.

Acceptance criteria:
- Unit tests simulate two validations completing out of order and assert only the latest result is applied.
- No regressions to existing search input/validation behavior.
- `make test` passes.

Priority rationale:
- Medium: improves correctness of an always-on UX feature.
evidence: crates/tui/src/action/variants.rs:382-394 defines ValidateSpl and SplValidationResult without including the validated query or request id
crates/tui/src/runtime/side_effects/searches.rs:169-216 spawns validate_spl() calls and sends SplValidationResult with no correlation
plan: Extend SPL validation actions to include a request id (and store latest id in App search state).
Update side effects to attach the request id to results.
Update App reducer to ignore stale validation results.
Add tests covering out-of-order completion and ensuring the latest result wins.
Verify by running `make test` and confirming TUI tests pass.

- Risk: added dependencies. Mitigation: use minimal, well-maintained clap ecosystem crates (`clap_complete`, `clap_mangen`) behind a small module boundary.

Acceptance criteria:

- Tests assert the subcommands produce non-empty output and exit 0 (no network required).

tasks.title: Add splunk-cli jobs results subcommand (paginate/export)

- Expansion: add `--all` to iterate pages until completion and stream to stdout/file; add `jobs events` later if needed.

Risks and mitigations:
- Risk: large outputs. Mitigation: default to a safe count; document `--output-file`; consider NDJSON streaming as a follow-up.

Acceptance criteria:
- CLI help includes examples and documents pagination flags.
- Hermetic tests cover arg parsing and formatting glue; ignored live tests validate server behavior.
- `make test` passes.

Priority rationale:
- Medium: meaningful workflow unlock with moderate effort.

plan: Extend the CLI jobs command surface to include a `results` subcommand with count/offset/output flags.
Implement handler that calls `SplunkClient::get_search_results` and formats via existing formatter.

tasks.title: Refactor SplunkClient to allow concurrent API calls (remove TUI mutex bottleneck)
tasks.description:
Opportunity type: performance / strategic refactor

Evidence:
- The TUI side-effects layer documents that all API calls are serialized behind a single `Arc<Mutex<SplunkClient>>` because client methods require `&mut self` for session refresh (`crates/tui/src/runtime/side_effects/mod.rs`).
- CLI `list-all` explicitly fetches resources sequentially for the same reason (`crates/cli/src/commands/list_all/fetchers.rs`).

Why it matters:
- Serialized calls increase perceived latency (slow screen loads, slow multi-resource commands) and increase the chance that background refreshes starve user-triggered actions.
- Making the client concurrency-friendly unlocks parallel health aggregation, faster list-all, and smoother TUI refresh behavior.

Proposed approach:
- Minimal viable slice:
  - Refactor auth/session token refresh to use interior mutability so request methods can be `&self` (e.g., session manager behind an async lock with a singleflight refresh path).
  - Update the client API surface accordingly and remove the global mutex in TUI (`Arc<SplunkClient>` instead of `Arc<Mutex<...>>`).
  - Introduce a concurrency limit (semaphore) at the UI edge to prevent flooding Splunk.
- Expansion:
  - Parallelize multi-call aggregations (health aggregate, list-all resources) using `join!` with bounded concurrency.

Risks and mitigations:
- Risk: race conditions around token refresh. Mitigation: singleflight refresh with strict invariants and tests for concurrent callers.
- Risk: wide blast radius (signature changes). Mitigation: staged refactor with clear compilation gates and workspace-wide updates.

Acceptance criteria:
- New tests covering concurrent token refresh behavior and ensuring correctness for both API-token and session-token auth.
- Demonstrable latency reduction for health aggregation and list-all (documented benchmark or measured in a test/bench).
- `make test` and `make ci` pass.

Priority rationale:
- Medium: hig...
evidence: crates/tui/src/runtime/side_effects/mod.rs explains all API calls serialize on Arc<Mutex<SplunkClient>> due to &mut self requirement
crates/cli/src/commands/list_all/fetchers.rs:16-20 documents sequential resource fetch due to &mut SplunkClient
plan: Design the new auth/session management interior-mutability model (singleflight refresh, clear invariants).
Refactor `SplunkClient` methods to take `&self` where possible and update call sites across CLI/TUI.
Remove the TUI shared client mutex and add bounded concurrency controls at the runtime edge.
Parallelize health aggregation and list-all resource fetching with bounded concurrency.
Add concurrency-focused tests (token refresh races) and update any affected public API docs.
Verify by running `make ci` and confirming latency improvements via benchmarks/logs.
